explanation.text:
Explanation
Financial Accounting is based on a systematic method of recording transactions of any business according to the accounting principles. It is the first and original form of accounting process.

text: Which of the following branches of accounting was first developed?
subject: ACCOUNTS PRINCIPLES OF ACCOUNTS

explanation.text:
Explanation
Accrual concept is the most fundamental principle of accounting which requires recording revenues when they are earned and not when they are received in cash, and recording expenses when they are incurred and not when they are paid.

text: The accounting convention which states that the performance of a business should be determined by matching all expenses against revenues is?
subject: ACCOUNTS PRINCIPLES OF ACCOUNTS

explanation.text:
Explanation
Bookkeeping is the recording of financial transactions  in which all of the financial transactions of the business (consisting of income and expenses) are entered into a database. It uses records recorded in the ledger.
Ledgers is a book or other collection of financial accounts.

text: The process of bookkeeping includes records produced from?
subject: ACCOUNTS PRINCIPLES OF ACCOUNTS

explanation.text:
Explanation
No official explanation is available for this question at this time. Please check contributions posted by others below. If you can provide an explanation to help other student learn, please click here

text: Musa, a prepaid customer of XYZ and KLM, bought N1500 recharge card from XYZ, and N2000 recharge recharge card from KLM, for business calls. The entry to record these transaction is debit?

options.text: telephone N3,500 credit XYZ and KLM, N3,500

subject: ACCOUNTS PRINCIPLES OF ACCOUNTS

explanation.text:
Explanation
No official explanation is available for this question at this time. Please check contributions posted by others below. If you can provide an explanation to help other student learn, please click here

Explanation
Drawings is the withdrawals from a business by a business owner for his personal use. It represents a reduction of owners' equity (capital) in the business. 
 Drawings account have a debit balance which increases assets (remember in the balance sheet, assets are recorded on the debit side of the account while liabilities have a credit ballance). Hence drawings would reduce owners capital and increase the asset balance.

text: If Odukoya takes money out of business bank account for his own private use, the effect of the transaction is?

options.text: increase in assets and increase in capital
increase in liabilities and decrease in capital
decrease in capital and increase in assets
decrease in capital and decrease in assets

subject: ACCOUNTS PRINCIPLES OF ACCOUNTS

explanation.text:
Explanation
Current Liabilities = Notes payable + Accounts payable + Accrued expenses + Unearned revenue + Current portion of long term debt + other short term debt.
From the question above, Loans from friends and creditors are liabilities the rest are assets

text:
Use the information to answer below to answer questions 

i Operating machines
ii Furniture
iii Fixtures and fitting
iv Loan from friends
V Creditors

What are the current liabilities?
subject: ACCOUNTS PRINCIPLES OF ACCOUNTS

explanation.text:
Explanation
Fixed assets are assets which are purchased for long-term use and are not likely to be converted quickly into cash, such as land, buildings, furniture and equipment. From the question above they include; i, ii & iii

period one income =
N1,000- N780 pay out = N220 balance

text: What is the balance of cash with the petty cashier at the end of period 1?
subject: ACCOUNTS PRINCIPLES OF ACCOUNTS

explanation.text:
Explanation
A cash discount is a deduction allowed by some sellers of goods or by some providers of services in order to motivate customers to pay within a specified time. It will be recorded on the debit and credit side of the cash book. Recall the three column cashbook has the cash, bank and discount columns. The debit side of the discount will record cash discount received while the credit side will record discount allowed

text: Cash discount is often recorded on?

options.text: the debit side of the cash book
the credit side of the cash book
the folio column of the cash book
both credit and debit side of the cash book

subject: ACCOUNTS PRINCIPLES OF ACCOUNTS

explanation.text:
Explanation
Standing order is an instruction to a bank by an account holder or customer to make regular fixed payments to a particular person or organization on their behalf.

text: The standing order is a payment instruction given by a?
subject: ACCOUNTS PRINCIPLES OF ACCOUNTS

text: Which of the should not be added or subtracted from the bank statement balance to determine the adjust cash balance?
subject: ACCOUNTS PRINCIPLES OF ACCOUNTS

explanation.text:
Explanation
Balance per bank is the ending cash balance appearing on a bank statement.
Hence we have; cashbook balance + unpresented cheques + direct bank debit - (direct credit + cashbook credit)
20,000+5200+1000 - (1000+500) = 24,700

text:
Given:

Balance as per cash book...................N20,000
Unpresented cheques........................N5, 200
Direct credit to the bank..................N1, 000
Direct debit from the bank.................N1, 000
Credit in the cash book....................N500

Calculate the balance as per bank statement at the end of the year?
subject: ACCOUNTS PRINCIPLES OF ACCOUNTS

explanation.text:
Explanation
Capital = Assets - liabilities
Assets = Fixed assets + current assets + drawings
2000 + 4000 + 200 = 6200
Liabilities = current liabilities + longterm loans
1200 + 2000 = 3200
6200 - 3200 = 3000

text:
Use the information below to answer questions

Total current assets..................N2,000
Total fixed assets....................N4,000
Current liabilities...................N1,200
Drawings..............................N200
Long-term loan........................N2,000

Determine the capital of the business?
subject: ACCOUNTS PRINCIPLES OF ACCOUNTS

explanation.text:
Explanation
Working capital = current assets - current liabilities
2000 - 1200 = 800

text:
Use the information below to answer questions

Total current assets..................N2,000
Total fixed assets....................N4,000
Current liabilities...................N1,200
Drawings..............................N200
Long-term loan........................N2,000
subject: ACCOUNTS PRINCIPLES OF ACCOUNTS

explanation.text:
Explanation
Current assets include cash and other assets that are expected to be converted to cash within a year. Option A ''Stock, bills receivable, cash and debtors'' is correct.
- Stock are goods bought for the purpose of resale
- Bills receivable are incurred as a result of credit sales
- Cash is the available money at hand
- A debtor is a person, company, or other entity that owes money.

text: Which of the following items are current assets?

options.text: Stock, bills receivable, cash and debtors
Stock, bill payable, cash and debtors
Stock, bad debt, bills receivable and cash
Stock, work-in-progress, cash and bills payable

subject: ACCOUNTS PRINCIPLES OF ACCOUNTS

text: Which of the following is a debit item in the purchases ledger control account.
subject: ACCOUNTS PRINCIPLES OF ACCOUNTS

explanation.text:
Explanation
Recall sales ledger control account are used to track trade debtors, that is goods sold on credit. We already know that we debit all income and credit expenses. The debit side of the account contains interest charged by suppliers because the goods were sold on credit and its considered an income

text: Which of the following is an item in the debit side of the sales ledger control account?

options.text: Transfer of credit balances from credit control account
Transfer of debit balance from creditors control account

subject: ACCOUNTS PRINCIPLES OF ACCOUNTS

explanation.text:
Explanation
Service costs are the costs incurred to provide or deliver a service. They have the element of manufacturing cost but are not directly involved in production. They include cost such as the use of power and water; fee for use of furniture carpeting/curtains, costs such as cleaning of common areas, costs of concierge or maintenance of common garden.

text: The cost incurred by departments that support the production departments with such activities as maintenance, production control and storage are called?
subject: ACCOUNTS PRINCIPLES OF ACCOUNTS

subject: ACCOUNTS PRINCIPLES OF ACCOUNTS

explanation.text:
Explanation
A receipts and payments account is a summary of actual cash receipts and payments extracted from the cash book over a certain period. All cash received and paid during the period whether capital or revenue is included in this account. It is the equivalent of a cashbook

text: Receipt and payments account is a summary of the?
subject: ACCOUNTS PRINCIPLES OF ACCOUNTS

explanation.text:
Explanation
Accumulated fund = Total assets - Liabilities
20,000 + 15,000 +4,700 - (6,500+4800+650)
39,700-11,950 = 27,750

text:
Given:

Furniture and fittings..................N20,000
Equipment...............................N15,000

Bar creditors...........................N4,800
Subscription in arrears.................N4,700
Subscription in advance.................N650

What is the accumulated fund?

text:
i Space occupied by each department.
ii Average value of stock held by each department.
iii Departmental turnover.
iv Number of articles sold by each department .

From the information above, the two most logical bases for apportioning expenses that are common to departments are?
subject: ACCOUNTS PRINCIPLES OF ACCOUNTS

explanation.text:
Explanation
sales volume of Q = 23,400
If sales volume of Q doubles that of p which is \(\frac{1}{3}\) of R we have;
for P = 23,400 ÷ 2p
p = \(\frac{23,400}{2}\) = 11,700
Since R is \(\frac{1}{3}\) of P, hence we have,
R= 1/3P
R = 3 x P
R =  \(\frac{3}\times{11700}\)  = 35,100

text:
Use the information to answer question below

.........................     Departments
...........................                      P                Q                R
Sales value...............                           N23,400
Selling expenses..........      1,100         N1,400         N1,280
Administrative expenses...N1,400       N1,000          N1,020
Cost of sales.............      N6,900....    N6,700           N5,500

Sales value of department Q doubles that of p, which is 1/3 of R. Depreciation which amounts to N1,800 is to be apportioned among the three departments in the ratio 3:5:7 respectively.

What is the sales value of department R?
subject: ACCOUNTS PRINCIPLES OF ACCOUNTS

explanation.text:
Explanation
Depreciation is considered an operating expense so it will be added to the expenses.
Total expense of P = Selling expenses +  Administrative expenses +  depreciation
1100 + 1400 + \(\frac{3}{15}\) x 1800 
1100 + 1400 + 360 = 2,860

explanation.text:
Explanation
The primary objectives of branch accounting are better accountability and control since profitability and efficiency can be closely tracked for individual locations

text: Which of the following is a common cause of a discrepancy between head office and branch trial balance?
subject: ACCOUNTS PRINCIPLES OF ACCOUNTS

explanation.text:
Explanation
Recall that Sule and Ahmed have been sharing profit and losses equally. The admission of Khadija will only reduce the rate of losses and profits shared but will still be equally shared. The new sharing formula would be ;
\(\frac{2}{5}:{2}{5}:{1}{5}\)
\(\frac{2}{5}+{2}{5}+{1}{5}\) = \(\frac{5}{5}\) = 1

text: Sule and Ahmad are in partnership sharing profits and losses equally. If Khadija is admitted as new partner to take \(\frac{1}{5}\) as her share,  what is the new profit or loss sharing ratio?
subject: ACCOUNTS PRINCIPLES OF ACCOUNTS

explanation.text:
Explanation

partners salary - K              800

share of profit -  M  4020

                                          10500
Net profit b/d           10000
Int. on drawings: M    500


                                            
                                 10500

Profit sharing ratio M and K 3:2

Determine M's share of profit?

explanation.text:
Explanation
Assuming the partnership maintains a fixed capital balance P capital would be the balance brought down 20,000 (that is capital without drawings)

Explanation
K capital contributed = 10000
10000 - 1,000 - 2000 - 100 - 10 = 6880

Explanation
Realization account refers to an account opened by the firm when it goes to dissolution to record the profit made from the sale of assets and loss suffered on the settlement of liabilities. When non-assets are converted to cash its called realization

text: In a partnership account, conversation of non-cash assets into cash is referred to as?
subject: ACCOUNTS PRINCIPLES OF ACCOUNTS

explanation.text:
Explanation
Premium shares = Issue price per share – Face value/par value per share x No of shares.
Issue price = N1.50
Face value = N1
No. of shares = 750,000
1.50 - 1 = 0.50
0.50 x 750,000 = 375,000
Share Application or share allotment or Share capital A/c all are personal accounts as they represent money from the shareholders and when money is due, these are to be debited because of the rule "Debit the receiver".

options.text: credited with application and allotment N187, 500
debited with appllication and allotment N375,000
credited with application and allotment N375, 000
debited with application and allotment N187, 500

subject: ACCOUNTS PRINCIPLES OF ACCOUNTS

text:
Use the information below to answer questions below;

A company advertised and issued N750,000, 12% preference shares of N1 each to be issued at N1.50 per share. Applications for N1,370,000 were received at 30k per share. 70k per share (including premium) was due on allotment while 25k per share was due on each of the remaining two calls. All amounts due were received . Application money for 120,000 shares was refunded to unsuccessful applicants were allotment shares on pro-rata basis.
subject: ACCOUNTS PRINCIPLES OF ACCOUNTS

explanation.text:
Explanation
The Provision for Bad and Doubtful Debts will appear in the Balance Sheet. Next year, the actual amount of bad debts will be debited not to the Profit and Loss Account but to the Provision for Bad and Doubtful Debts Account which will then stand reduced.

text: Provision for bad and double debts in companies final accounts is treated in?
subject: ACCOUNTS PRINCIPLES OF ACCOUNTS

text: The book value per share is obtained by dividing?
subject: ACCOUNTS PRINCIPLES OF ACCOUNTS

explanation.text:
Explanation
Revenue expenses are incurred when a company purchases products or services necessary for generating revenue in the short term. They include overhead cost, maintenance cost of plants and equiptment.

text: Expenditure incurred on consumables and goods for resale is?
subject: ACCOUNTS PRINCIPLES OF ACCOUNTS

explanation.text:
Explanation
 Capital expenditures are money spent by a business or organization on acquiring or maintaining fixed assets, such as land, buildings, and equipment.

text: Replacement and renewal of fixed assets are?
subject: ACCOUNTS PRINCIPLES OF ACCOUNTS

explanation.text:
Explanation
The Consolidated Revenue Fund is an account that is owned and managed by the Federal Government, where all its revenues are paid. 
Remember in account we debit all incomes and credit all expenses. Recurrent expenditures would be credited to the consolidated fund. showing monies that have gone out of the fund.
Recurrent expenditure is expenditure, which does not result in the creation or acquisition of fixed assets (new or second-hand). It consists mainly of expenditure on wages, salaries and supplements, purchases of goods and services .

text: Which of the following is credited to the consolidated revenue fund?
subject: ACCOUNTS PRINCIPLES OF ACCOUNTS

explanation.text:
Explanation
Purpose of public sector is to provide public services. This  include public goods and governmental services such as the military, police, public education along with health care and those working for the government itself. These services are provided at a cheap and affordable rate to the citizens.

text: One of the reasons for the existence of the public sector is to?

options.text: Take adequate care of the needy
provide cheap services to all citizens

subject: ACCOUNTS PRINCIPLES OF ACCOUNTS

explanation.text:
Explanation
\(\frac{10}{100}\) x 100,000 = 10,000
cost of goods sold = sales - profit
100,000 - 10,000 = 90,000

text: If the gross profit margin is 10% of sales, what is the value of the cost of goods sold?
subject: ACCOUNTS PRINCIPLES OF ACCOUNTS

explanation.text:
Explanation
opening stock + cost of goods sold - closing stock = purchase
Remember COGS was given as;
cost of goods sold = sales - profit (10% of sales)
100,000 - 10,000 = 90,000
Hence we have;
purchase = 5,000 + 90000 - 5,600 = 90,600

text: If the opening stock is 5% of sales. calculate the purchases
subject: ACCOUNTS PRINCIPLES OF ACCOUNTS

explanation.text:
Explanation
The insurance premium to be taken to the profit and loss account will be the amount which could not be recovered by the trader on account of credit sales. It is a business loss, so is debited in the profit and loss account.
Insurance premium posted to the P/L account would be;
710 + 600 = 1310
